subharmonic functions

Let uuu be a non-negative continuous function on D‾∖{0}={z∈C∣0<∣z∣≤1}\cl{\D} \setminus \set{0} = \set{z \in \C \mid 0 < \abs{z} \leq 1}D∖{0}={z∈C∣0<∣z∣≤1} that is subharmonic on D∖{0}\D \setminus \set{0}D∖{0}. Suppose that u∣∂D≡0\res{u}{\partial\D} \equiv 0u∣∂D​≡0 and

lim⁡r→0+1r2log⁡ (1/r)∫{0<∣z∣<r}u(z) dλ(z)=0,\lim_{r\to0^+} \frac{1}{r^2\log\,\p{1/r}} \int_{\set{0 < \abs{z} < r}} u\p{z} \,\diff\lambda\p{z} = 0,r→0+lim​r2log(1/r)1​∫{0<∣z∣<r}​u(z)dλ(z)=0,

where integration is with respect to Lebesgue measure λ\lambdaλ on C\CC. Show that then u≡0u \equiv 0u≡0.
Solution.

Notice that if a<ba < ba<b, then

log⁡a≤log⁡b  ⟹  1log⁡ (1/a)≤1log⁡ (1/b).\log{a} \leq \log{b} \implies \frac{1}{\log\,\p{1/a}} \leq \frac{1}{\log\,\p{1/b}}.loga≤logb⟹log(1/a)1​≤log(1/b)1​.

Let R∈(0,1)R \in \p{0, 1}R∈(0,1) so that B(0,R)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{0, R}} \subseteq \DB(0,R)​⊆D. Thus, given any z∈B(0,R2)z \in B\p{0, \frac{R}{2}}z∈B(0,2R​), we have B(z,R4)‾⊆B(0,R)\cl{B\p{z, \frac{R}{4}}} \subseteq B\p{0, R}B(z,4R​)​⊆B(0,R) and so non-negativity of uuu and the sub-mean value property give

u(z)log⁡ (1/∣z∣)≤1log⁡ (1/∣z∣)1π(R/4)2∫B(z,R4)u(w) dλ(w)≤16πR2log⁡ (1/R)∫B(0,R)u(w) dλ(w)→R→0+0,\begin{aligned} \frac{u\p{z}}{\log\,\p{1/\abs{z}}} &\leq \frac{1}{\log\,\p{1/\abs{z}}} \frac{1}{\pi \p{R/4}^2} \int_{B\p{z,\frac{R}{4}}} u\p{w} \,\diff\lambda\p{w} \\ &\leq \frac{16}{\pi R^2\log\,\p{1/R}} \int_{B\p{0, R}} u\p{w} \,\diff\lambda\p{w} \xrightarrow{R\to0^+} 0, \end{aligned}log(1/∣z∣)u(z)​​≤log(1/∣z∣)1​π(R/4)21​∫B(z,4R​)​u(w)dλ(w)≤πR2log(1/R)16​∫B(0,R)​u(w)dλ(w)R→0+​0,​

by assumption. Set f(z)=log⁡1∣z∣f\p{z} = \log\frac{1}{\abs{z}}f(z)=log∣z∣1​ and for ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, let uε(z)=u(z)−εf(z)u_\epsilon\p{z} = u\p{z} - \epsilon f\p{z}uε​(z)=u(z)−εf(z) which is subharmonic on D∖{0}\D \setminus \set{0}D∖{0} since uuu is subharmonic and fff is harmonic.

uε(z)=f(z)(u(z)f(z)−ε)→∣z∣→0−∞u_\epsilon\p{z} = f\p{z}\p{\frac{u\p{z}}{f\p{z}} - \epsilon} \xrightarrow{\abs{z}\to0} -\inftyuε​(z)=f(z)(f(z)u(z)​−ε)∣z∣→0​−∞

by our previous calculation. Thus, for each ε\epsilonε, there exists rε>0r_\epsilon > 0rε​>0 such that uε≤0u_\epsilon \leq 0uε​≤0 on B(0,rε)‾∖{0}\cl{B\p{0, r_\epsilon}} \setminus \set{0}B(0,rε​)​∖{0}. By the maximum principle, uεu_\epsilonuε​ attains its maximum on ∂D∪∂B(0,rε)\partial\D \cup \partial B\p{0, r_\epsilon}∂D∪∂B(0,rε​). Since uε(z)=0u_\epsilon\p{z} = 0uε​(z)=0 for z∈∂Dz \in \partial\Dz∈∂D and uε(z)≤0u_\epsilon\p{z} \leq 0uε​(z)≤0 for z∈∂B(0,rε)z \in \partial B\p{0, r_\epsilon}z∈∂B(0,rε​), it follows that uε≤0u_\epsilon \leq 0uε​≤0 on all of D∖{0}\D \setminus \set{0}D∖{0}.

Letting ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, we see that u(z)≤0u\p{z} \leq 0u(z)≤0 on all of D∖{0}\D \setminus \set{0}D∖{0}, and so u≡0u \equiv 0u≡0, since u(z)≥0u\p{z} \geq 0u(z)≥0.
